author: pregnantbird

description.text:
Upon seeing tachyio's Deus Ex inspired prints, I was inspired to expand the same basic principle into usable lighting solutions. This is a scaled mock-up of a wall sconce that will eventually be 1.5' x 1.5' lit with low-energy consuming LEDs. I only wanted to see what the physical object would look like. so I modeled and printed it. the model itself could probably be used as a coaster for your favorite techno-punk beverage.
I will post more on my progress with the sconce as it materializes.
scale and print. No walls and 100% infill yielded best results for me with a .5mm nozzle. If you find any cool uses for this I'd be happy to hear.

comments.text: Nice work! Actually I think it would be cooler if the outline wasnt a cube. If its mounted on a wall, it could be designed to look like something reminiscent of nature or a cellular form, rather than a square. :)
comments.author: tachyio

title: The Devil Made Me Do It

description.text:
This is a remix of Andreas's superb original, Impy. The first version of this remix was done in about an hour by Skyler, one of my students. (Not bad for a fifth grader, huh?) I then made some modifications to Skyler's version and turned it into a kit we could print using our dual extruder printer and then assemble.  
I have another version that has the devil glancing back toward his pitchfork with his tongue slightly askew.

The red & brown main body and black & white eyes must be printed on a dual extruder printer. (Sorry!)   
The red pegs that are printed along with the body are used to attached the body to the base.   
The black pitchfork should just slide into the devil's hands.   
Be sure to print 2 copies of the eyes.  
We use Gorilla Glue to attach the eyes, teeth and belt buckle. Getting the teeth into place requires a bit of finesse. What I do is dab a small drop of glue into each of the teeth sockets then use a pointed tool to position the teeth into place.

comments.text: Hah, very nice! I think it's great that your students had some fun with him :)

title: Turnigy Talon Quad Copter Landing Gear

description.text: Simple replacement landing gear for a Turnigy Talon V2 carbon fiber quad copter. I found that the original parts were very easy to break, even from a soft landing and they around $10 to replace to i had to find a cheaper alternative. If you print it at a medium infill (50%) it's flexible enough to absorb a bit of impact without breaking. Should work well with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:162908 if you drill a small pilot-hole and use a self tapping screw
nice easy print, 50% infill to add a bit of flex but still strong. i printed with 3 shells but it really doesn't matter.

author: sakunamary

title: Bicycle helmet (Bell Ukon) coat rack peg hook

description.text:
A hook to hang a Bell Ukon or similar bike helmet on a coat rack.
This is designed for coat racks with mushroom shaped pegs. You slide the hook on the peg and leave it there. Then you hang your helmet on the hook when you come home.

With this hook you hang up your bike helmet with the top towards the wall, you put it on the wall in one motion by just doffing your helmet.
The hook is designed with the Bell Ukon helmet in mind, but should work with others that have a similarly shaped hole at the crown. See the red marks in the image. The wall side hole is sized for a peg with diameters of 8.3 mm and 16.1 mm and a thin stem of 16.8 mm.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 µm

Infill:

10 %

Notes:

This should print easily in PLA. No rafts or falsework needed. A brim may be useful to avoid warping.
Print with low infill and many (≥3) shells.

The FreeCAD file contains a spreadsheet where these sizes, especially for the peg hole, can be changed. Afterwards, check that the shape is still valid, convert it to a mesh and export that.

There is a bit of design history in the Helmhaken folder of my github 3d printing repo.

This is a mash-up of my coat rack peg extension and my wall-mounted helmet hook, which i published elsewhere.

title: 0.05mm Increment Grip for M3x0.5pitch 42ridge Knurled Thumbscrew

description.text:
A 'calibrated' thumbscrew grip.

Allows you to accurately correlate how much you turn it with the distance the hotbed will move. ( Assumes you have the usual M3 0.5mm pitch thumbscrew thread. )
ie: Rotate to the next:
... DIFFERENTLY-sized knob and your hotbed will move 0.05mm.
... SAME-sized knob and your hotbed will move 0.1mm.
One complete rotation is - of course - a 0.5mm hotbed movement.

Mount it either:
1) Completely remove one thumbscrew and slip this 'grip' over the top. Re-attach the thumbscrew. Repeat for each thumbscrew. This allows you to lift and disengage the 'grip' without removing the thumbscrew, rotate it to a specific orientation, and drop it back down to re-engage the thumbscrew knurls.
It can be useful to have all of the grips oriented the same way after you level the bed.

2) By slipping it onto your thumbscrew from below. I recommend a small dab of rubber/contact cement to keep it in place, and still allow you to easily remove it.

Printer:

Anycubic i3 Mega

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

The 0.3mm layers, 0.4mm nozzle, 20% honeycomb fill, works fine with PLA
Smaller nozzles will probably improve the grip of the inside ridges on the thumbscrew knurls, but I don't know. Bigger than 0.4mm nozzles will almost certainly reduce grip on the knurls or simply not fit.

comments.text: Thanks a lot !
comments.author: id6548437

comments.text: Next time you need to remove the hoptbed plate, or just feel like removing all the thumbscrews, toss the knobs on the top of each thumbscrew. They'll never fall off, and after you get your bed really perfectly flat you can push the knobs up to disengage them, rotate them all to face exactly the same direction, and push  them back onto the knurls again. ...just for that extra OCD satisfaction. :)
comments.author: id6548437

comments.text:
As a function of knowing how much the bed should move versus how much the knob turns I have realised that there is a bit pf slack/play/delay in the bed movement. Particularly, or maybe exclusively if you switch from moving it up to moving it downwards.
It usually happens when i am adjusting that first layer height. Like I will have been printing 0.3mm layers,, and then need to refine the height a bit for printing a 0.1mm layer print. I'll be doing that first layer fine tune and know that I need to come back the opposite direction from my previous adjustment about half way - often when turning the knob 0.05mm..ie between each adjacent different sized knob - and yet the bed may or may not move accordingly. Given a bump it will usually immediately comply, but be aware that when doing fine adjustments that due to friction between the bed and the screw there may be some delay in set and effect. Or the bed simply may not obey at all until you gently bump it vertically.
comments.author: id6548437

comments.text: Hi,
comments.author: BETLOG

comments.text: No. The slack is not between the knob and the thumbscrew. The slack is between the bed and the bolt.
comments.author: id6548437

comments.text: ok ! sorry i misunderstood
comments.author: BETLOG

comments.text: Exactly :)

description.text:
I bought a used Logitech G5 for 5€ unfortunately it was missing the weight cartridge.

This is a compatible cartridge which uses M6 and M4 nuts as weights.

One M6 nut is about 2,1g
One M4 nut is about 0,7g

You can Load a total of 9 M6 and M4 nuts each. You can load a total of 25g in weights. The original logitech weights give you a max of 27g, so its pretty close.
The fully loaded cartridge comes in at about 34g.

print_settings.Notes:: This model has been modified from a previous version. It now no longer requires any support material but some assembly is required.

description.text:
This is a Japanese-style lantern based off a design found online (comparison included). Modeled in SketchUp (file included), it is printed out in multiple parts that require assembly. The bottom requires support material, the top does not.

Users are encouraged to modify and improve this design which is why the SketchUp file is also included.

Print Quantity (file names):

(1) Base (Feet.stl)
(1) Bottom (Btm.stl)
(2) Brace Rings (BracesX2.stl)
(6) Lantern Panels (PanelsX6.stl)
(1) Top (Top.stl)

Fasten the parts with either hot glue or friction welding.

Use a keychain ring as a solid means of hanging the lantern, or simply place it on a table top. The feet are optional. We use felt squares hot glued to the bottom of the feet to give the lantern more character and a better finish.

Use only LED's to light the lantern. Do not use candles because it's an obvious fire hazard.

description.text:
Spool holder using blind rivets or 1.75mm filaments as axles

This is a spool holder design for Geeetech I3 Pro B with Acrylic 8mm frame.

Though there are many spool holder designs, this particular one is different by the fact that it doesn't use ball-bearings (as the vast majority do) and instead it uses blind rivets as bushings and for the axle it can use either the rivet mandrel (rivet stem) or a piece of 1.75mm filament (PLA, ABS, ...)

The rivets are easier to get than ball-bearings and they are much cheaper. (I got a box with 6 different types of rivets and 320 in total for around $3).

The rivet itself is used as a bushing and the mandrel(stem) is used as the axle. 1.75mm PLA or ABS filament can be used as axle too (if the force on the axle is below its breaking point).
The rivet is usually made of aluminium, while the mandrel(stem) is usually made from steel.

The spool hlder itself was designed to fit the Geeetech I3 Pro B made with acrylic 8mm frame. The spool holder arms are 48mm long.

I designed all the parts using FreeCAD and it tries to compensate for the XY expansion/shrinkage of your printer. The XY expansion/shrinkage is a parameter in the FreeCAD project files and it is used for part design. You can modify the parameter using your own value and then re-generate the parts.

The design uses 0.2mm for the XY expansion/shrinkage and I got this value after I printed my M3 bolt & nut calibration and then comparing the printed model with a real M3 nut and bolt.

The end result should be a spool holder requiring very few post-printing adjustments.

Needed materials

  • 8 x 1/8"x1/8" blind rivets (3.2x3.2 mm)
  • 4 x M3 nuts
  • 4 x M3x30 bolts

For a complete spool holder you'll need to print:

  • 2 x Spool Holder A parts
  • 2 x Spool Holder B parts
  • 4 x Wheels

Geeetech I3 Pro B

Notes:

Standard blind rivet axle

This spool holder design is a proof of concept using the standard blind rivet elements as bushings and axles.
The blind rivets are much cheaper than the ball-bearings and in many situations they'll get the job done.

After playing a bit with the plastic wheels using rivets as bushings, I realized the 1.75mm filament can be a good axle too in certain projects (where the force on the axle is not too strong to shear the filament).

In the end, adding a bit of lubricant on the axle will always help reducing the friction and wear & tear.

Have fun using the rivet-based axles in your projects!

3 different types of blind rivets - from left to right: 1/8"x1/8"(3.2x3.2mm), 1/8"x1/4"(3.2x6.4mm), 1/8"x5/16"(3.2x7.9mm) push the rivet's mushroom to free it from the mandrel(stem) Rivet freed from its mandrel(stem) Rivet used as a wheel bushing. title: Universal Wireless Switch Access
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Merci de lire l'avertissement en cliquant sur le profil.
Pour la personne en situation de handicap, l’accès à l'ordinateur peut se révéler compliqué, en particulier avec les écrans tactiles lorsque l'usage des mains est compromis.
Heureusement, la plupart des systèmes d'exploitation (MacOs, IOS et Android) proposent, en série, des outils facilitant la navigation dans l'environnement informatique. Pour Windows, le logiciels Civikeys est utilisé : http://www.civikey.com/

Pour étendre encore ces possibilités, il est possible de connecter un contacteur externe qui permettra, par exemple, de faire défiler puis sélectionner les éléments et icônes présentés à l'écran.

En recherchant une solution aisée, simple et abordable de produire ce type de contacteur sans fils, il est apparu qu'en mixant un bouton bluetooth pour selfie avec un design prévu pour accueillir ce dernier, il était possible de disposer d'un contacteur sans fils capable de piloter ces systèmes à défilement et ainsi de réaliser des essais de contrôle de l'ordinateur.

un test du montage est disponible en cliquant le lien en bas du descriptif.

Selfie button : http://www.ebay.fr/itm/Wireless-Bluetooth-Remote-Shutter-Button-For-Selfie-Stick-Monopod-Phone-Pole-/291225033453?var=&hash=item43ce5d5aed:m:mUmMV0kekn8nJ4YI5C6bpmw

Thanks to read warnings by clicking profil.
Accessing a computer and specially a tablet without fingers is a challenge. Fortunaltely, most of the OS are equiped with accessibility tools designed to help users to access more easily their computer and tablet. For Windows, Civikeys virtual keyboard is used.
To further extend those possibility, it is possible to connect external switch to help, for example, with some screen scrolling to choose an item on it, to navigate and to select.

In my quest to find the cheaper and smarter solutions to build this kind of external switch, I found that mixing a very cheap selfie button, found on Ebay, with my own design maybe will be a interesting solution. Tests on different OS are shown on this video : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yma1FJRDItg&feature=youtu.be

title: Trartak - Orc War Triceratops for Scavengers Wargame

description.text:
"The Lords of the Beyond after being banished left behind a large strip of devastated land, with ghost towns, buildings, temples and a whole range of localities. Rumors that in these places existed treasures, weapons and a whole range of fantastic things, began to arrive in the ears of the people of our world.

Individuals in search of fame and fortune have decided to enter these cursed lands in search of these prizes. Organized in small groups, they enter these lands and there they face dangers. This is the premise of Scavengers, a skirmish game in the devastated lands, where you lead a group of adventurers in search of fame and fortune.

Extracted from Alabar Chronicle´s, a Scavenger Guide to Our World"

Introduction

Scavengers is a table top miniature war game for fighting skirmishes with fantasy/steampunk figures. Two players fight a small scale combat with five to ten miniatures on each side (a hero and your henchmen). The game is easy to learn and play, though there is enough depth that it will take time and experience to master.

The game was designed around three core premises.

a) You can download our 3D models or use any miniatures in their collection. Thus, the game is not specifically designed to any particular manufacturer or company. But if you like to help the game dev, please download our models! (They are free and paid...)

b) It is important that the miniatures on the table be the focus of the game. In the end, miniature gaming should be about miniatures (and fun!)

c) A large background - We´ll develop new units, histories and game scenarios. But we need your help, sending suggestions to improve the game!

I hope you like our game and have fun! Ahh, an important thing: this is the basic core rules, our idea is releasing other books to improve the game!

This is on Orc War Triceratops. It´s a huge figure! You need to print 1 for a stand. Our gaming site is coming with our core book, game lore and a lot of new things!

Note: You don´t need a base for it.

title: 3D Neuron
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 3D Neuron model intended for visualization of the ion movement during the process of action potential. It contains sodium channels, potassium channels, sodium-potassium pumps, calcium channels and neurotransmitters.
This model is directed for teachers to use in class but it can be printed by students as well.

Obs: This is not an anatomic model. This neuron was designed for physiology viewing purposes so be aware that some structures may not be anatomically accurate.
NGSS

Instructions for usage and printing

Use and Assembling Manual
Ana P. Felici¹; Daniel F. Frigo¹; Danilo Fernandes¹; Laura Rocha¹; Marina Bowkunouvicz¹; Pedro M. Martins¹
¹Undergraduates from the Institute of Biological Sciences from the University of São Paulo

Neurônio em potencial is a model created by students of the Undergraduate Program in Biological Sciences at the Institute of Biosciences of the University of São Paulo (IB/USP). The focus of the project was to develop a tridimensional model of a neuron for neurophysiological studies of, more specifically, action potentials.

To build the model, however, it was necessary to make some changes on the anatomy of the cell to make manipulation during physiological studies easier, as physiology should be prioritized, given the objectives of the project. Therefore, a anatomically trustworthy prototype should not be expected when using this model and that should be emphasized whenever the Neurônio em potencial is used on class.

1- PRINTING

To put the Neurônio em potencial together, it will be necessary to print the specified amount of the following pieces:
1 (one) basis piece;
2 (two) axonium pieces;
1 (one) cell body and dendrites piece;
1 (one) Ca 2+ channels;
1 (one) Neurotransmitter receptor;
9 (nine) type 1 slides;
3 (three) type 2 slides;
2 (two) Na+/K+ pumps;
2 (two) hooks.

All the pieces should be printed using ABS plastic (acrylonitrile butadiene styrene). On some places, there is only one color of plastic available, so it is recommended to paint the model after printing it. To do so, the best option is to use spray paint. It is also recommended to use a primer under the paint.
It is recommended that: (1) each channel type has a different color; (2) the myelin sheath is on a different color from the rest of the axon.

Besides the printed pieces, it is needed:
Small spheres (like beads) to represent the ions and neurotransmitters, divided in:

  • 2 (two) neurotransmitters;
    -9 (six) K+ ions;
    -6 (six) Na+ ions.
    The spheres must be compatible to the size of the slides. If they are small, more than one can be used on the channels.
    Pins to represent ions on the Na+/K+ pumps, as the pumps as too small for beads. It is needed:
    -4 (four) K+ ions;
    -6 (six) Na+ ions.

2- Assembling

First, put the pieces together the pieces that compose the cell body (calcium channels, basis, two axonium pieces and cell body with dendrites). To do that, it is recommended universal glue.
The result should look like the model on Figure 1;

Figure 1: Model after gluing.
After that, the channels must be put on their places :
The Na+ channels must be put on the left side, where there are a series of aligned holes.A total of 3 type 1 slides must be put on the body cell region. Type 2 slides must be put on the axon tube, with the perforated side facing the inner side of the tube, as in Figure 2A. On the regions separated by the myelin sheath, the slides must be united using hooks, like in Figure 2B.
The K+ channels must be put on the right side, where there are unaligned holes. In this step, 6 type 1 slides will be used, as seen on Figure 2C.
There are two holes on the back of the tube. The Na+/K+ must be put there, like in figure 2D.

Figure 2: 2.A)Na+ slides placement; 2.B)Hooks placement; 2.C)K+ slides placement; 2.D)Na+/K+ pumps placement.
The result should look like the model on Figure 3. Check if the pieces are glued to each other. Check if the channels and slides move like a seesaw and if the Na+/K+ pumps rotate, as that will be necessary to simulate the action potential.

3- Usage

Before starting up, the ion spheres should be placed at the slides (one for each slide), they should also be in a way that they stay at a leaning position (Figure 3). You should also place three Na+ ions (pins) and two K+ ions in each one of the pumps. At last, place the neurotransmitters spheres inside the basis piece, on its holes.
You should start by talking about the different ion concentrations both inside and outside the neuron (high Na+ and Cl- inside the neuron, and low on the outside, as for K+, the opposite is true) and then say that these concentration differences make it so that the inner surface of the cell has a
Figure 3:Channels placement potential of approximately -65 mV, that is, if you take the outside of the cell as a neutral reference.
Now, draw attention to the fact that the Na+/K+ pumps are of great importance to keep this difference, called resting potential, since they hydrolyze one ATP molecule to externalize three sodium ions and internalize two potassium ions. While you say that, turn the pumps around and show the ion exchange. Remind everyone that there are Na+ channels and K+ channels that always stay open, but they were hidden so the model is of easier visualization.
Later, show a chart that represents the membrane voltage variation during the action potential, the Na+ conductance and the K+ conductance, as you can see on Figure 4. Comment that, when the neuron gets stimulated, the sodium channels open up, and that the influx of said ion makes other channels open as well (Positive Feedback Loop), causing the plasmatic membrane to get depolarized.
You should also say that, due to the depolarization, the Potassium channels start to open up as well, but the same feedback effect doesn’t happen to them.
This opening is related to the repolarization of the membrane and its latter hyperpolarization. You should always remember to point out each stage on the chart.
Now, use your copy of Neuronio em Potencial. Say that the neuron got stimulated, and make it so the first Na+ slide tumbles down, since all the Na+ slides are lined up, each one will move the next, this way, displaying the positive feedback loop. Right after you move the first slide, start tumbling the Potassium slides, which, since they are in a alternating positions, need to be moved one by one (this way displaying that there is no feedback loop)
Besides that, every potassium slide must go back to its original position after they tumble down, the same shouldn’t be done to the sodium slides. Explain that this happens because the sodium channels go through a refractory period after they open, and the potassium slides, don’t. While the model moves, return to the chart and relate the whole dynamic.
When the movement is over, say that the depolarization wave leads to the opening of the Calcium channels and the influx of said ion. Ca2+ then, stimulates the release of vesicles with neurotransmitters, which may may have an inhibitory or excitatory response on other neurons. To display this, you should use a long and narrow object that represents the Calcium ion, poke the spheres that represent the neurotransmitters, which will roll down the hole and fall down on the Neurotransmitter receptor piece.

Figure 4: Graphical representation of action potential.

4- References

KANDEL, E., SCHWARTZ, J.H. & JESSEL, M. 1991. Principles of Neural Science. 3 rd ed. Elsevier, Ed. New York, 1135p.
LENT, R. 2001. Cem bilhões de neurônios: conceitos fundamentais de neurociência. Editora Atheneu, São Paulo, 698p.

author: archie73

description.text:
I was going to print Ducky the Lop Eared Bunny for my kid, but when I saw how big it was, I decided it would make a good piggy bank. So I pulled it into Meshmixer and hollowed it out. And like all good piggy banks, there is no way to get the coins out without breaking it. My little boy loves putting coins in it. When and if he ever fills it up, I plan to take a hole saw to the bottom.

The coin slot is 30mm because that easily fits all American coins that I had on hand. It should work for most foreign coins, but I do not know if anyone uses a bigger coin than that.

I print in PLA because my printer is in a family area. On my ANET A8 this was a 56 hour print. Inland Yellow 1.75mm PLA. .1mm layer, .4mm nozzle, 200deg, 5% infill, and yes you will need supports because of the chin and the right ear.

Confession: Some little boy clicked the power strip off during print, so I actually printed in two parts and glued them together. That same little boy thought the headless half print was the greatest thing ever, so Daddy had to measure and fix it after a little boy went to bed.

UPDATE 8-3-17 - I printed this back in may. Since then my little boy has happily crammed every coin he finds into it. It currently weighs about a pound. He likes to carry it around the apartment, and yesterday he was throwing it around in the kitchen. We expected it to fail, but surprisingly the PLA has not cracked yet. I think I might do a charmander as the next one.
Timeular Cube

author: takai

description.text:
The Lady of Elche or Lady of Elx is a limestone bust that was discovered in 1897 at L'Alcúdia, an archaeological site on a private estate two kilometers south of Elche, Spain. It is currently exhibited in the National Archaeological Museum of Spain in Madrid.

It is generally known as an Iberian artifact from the 4th century BC, although the artisanship suggests strong Hellenistic influences. According to The Encyclopedia of Religion, the Lady of Elche is believed to have a direct association with Tanit, the goddess of Carthage, who was worshiped by the Punic-Iberians.

title: Belt Clip - Sporty's JD-200 & SP-400 Aviation Handheld Radios
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a belt clip for a Sporty's JD-200 and SP-400 handheld aviation COM and NAV radio. Pilots often carry a spare handheld radio in case the electrical system goes out they can still talk, especially in a rented or shared plane.
These Sporty's radios also have an OBI to let a pilot use VOR beacons for in flight navigation and also line up with the runway localizer on ILS runways, the SP-400 even does glideslope.
Sporty's shop sells a $10 +shipping metal clip accessory for their radios but I am too cheap to bother with that when I might break it off. I want to be able to clip to my headset bag or lower leg cargo pocket more than I need to clip to my belt, also to clip to my collar so the antenna is up if I need the radio in a power outage.
Piston planes have magnetos like a lawnmower so even if the power from the alternator and battery is out the spark plugs will still fire and the engine and most instruments will still work though there are no lights, radios, or avionics.
Untested design, but should be close enough that if you really need you can just bore out the screw holes or grind no more than a mm of plastic. This might need more plastic on the top side of both the base and clip for the spring to lever against. I also need to print and verify the screw hole placements. Don't forget to acetone/ABS glue the leverage pad to the base if you make this. No warranty, I am not responsible for the loss of your radio or anything which results from that. My radio, an older Sporty's JD-200, has markings that a belt clip assembly requires 2x M3 screws which extend no more than 3mm into the radio, that means no more than 3mm of thread sticking out of the clip assembly.

I found this on Thingiverse when listing the belt clip, an external power supply which looks to work with other Sporty's radios including the JD-200, if you like to listen when at home or you work at a FBO. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1092186

title: Beyond UMO & UM2 Slideblocks by Gudo & Neotko - GT2 Open Belt
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a Beyond Slideblocks V2 that I made with Gudo

The adapters allow to use it on Ultimaker Original, and if the user ever upgrades the thin 6mm shafts & changes the hotend to um2 he can (with some drill and firmware changes) use the whole umo+ bed as um2 does. Ofc to do that the user would need to know how to change the firmware, change endstop places, etc etc. I will do a manual about that as soon I get time.

This slideblocks, vs others on umo, give a few extra mm of print area. Also is made for GT2 Open Belts. I used my 303T belts, did 'cut them' and removed 7 tooths to use it.

I truly don't have much time as right now so I can't do a proper manual, but any experienced used would guess how to use them very fast.

This uses x16 m2.5 nuts & 16 screws M2.5mm of 10mm long for um2 and um3 (indeed they work for um3) and.

For UMO+ it uses x24 m2.5 nuts, x8 M2.5mm 10mm long and x8 M2.5 16mm long. Also it will need x8 m2.5 for the adapters that hold the shaft in place.

Apart of the m2.5 you will need x4 M3 nuts and x4 M3 16mm long screws for the tension part.

I left the STEP file so anyone can change anything if needed. Have fun!

Print slow so you don't need to manually clean it, I for example printed it at 50-60mm/s and had to file a bit for the very small tolerances. No biggie, but I prefer to spend 10mins cleaning than 4 extra hours :D

The Left and Front slideblocks have holes to insert the endstops. The big one is for the Left, the small one for the Front slideblock. You can a) Glue it, b) Fuse with heat a bit the plastics so it never moves or c) Print very slow and use the tight fit.

title: Orange Pi Zero + Expansion Board Case

description.text:
Update 25th Sept 2017 - Source file in Fusion 360 format has been uploaded.

Summary

This is a case for the Orange Pi Zero with the expansion board module, a super low cost (US$7) mini computer like the Raspberry Pi Zero, but with built-in wired & wifi networking and more processing power. Perfect for using with Octoprint to control 3D printers.

For a case without the expansion board module, see my other design.

Note that this is not for the Plus model.

Features

  • Slim design
  • Vent opening
  • Multiple options
  • Easy print

The Base

There are two options - one just the base model, one with a mounting ear (perfect for 2020 aluminium profiles).

There is a 3mm hole for fitting the antenna through.

You can mount the board with four M3 6mm screws, but it's not necessary because the case holds the boards in place quite well.

The Cover

There are two options - one with slot vent, one with honeycomb vent. They are otherwise the same.

The cover is friction fitted to the base with no screws needed, and is quite snug.

Printing

Those in the pictures are printed on a VORON CoreXY, in Filamentive black recycled PLA, with a 0.6mm nozzle, 0.28mm layer height, 3 top/bottom layers, and 3 perimeters.

author: deanallenjones

description.text: The design files for this thing have been removed as a protest against Stratasys after their decision to file a patent infringement lawsuit against Microboards Technology. Their decision is extremely destructive and also underlines that the patent system is obsolete as it no longer serves any purpose for the betterment of society. Its main role is as a blunt weapon used by incumbents to hamper innovation. I see absolutely no reason to continue indirectly supporting Stratasys by providing free content to Thingiverse.

A modular electromagnetic accelerator that actually works...;) Warning: This project involves the use of a capacitor bank that contains more than enough energy to kill you. Do not attempt to build this unless you know what you are doing !
(There is a real possibility of poking an eye out or qualifying for a Darwin Award if you make a mistake...) The inspiration to create this came from reading the books "Kristian Birkeland - The First Space Scientist" (available from Springer) and "Zero To Eighty" by Edwin Fitch Northrup.

Each module contains a high voltage charger, an optical trigger, capacitor bank, voltage indicator, accelerator coil and switch circuitry. When the projectile interrupts an infrared beam at one end, it triggers a pulse of several hundred amps through the acceleration coil. The pulse peaks after approximately 4 ms. The projectile is then accelerated through the module. This is a modular design that uses optical triggers. Because of this, it is possible to stack several modules to achieve more power (each module weighs approx 1 Kg) If you want to see the this thing in action, there is a video on YouTube: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KeSjeUIltcI, and on my blog: http://www.timeexpander.com/wordpress/archives/5124 (norwegian only - sorry) Please be very careful if you plan on building something like this. I am myself an amateur regarding electronics and I can make no promises or guarantees regarding the safety of the electronics or design. Parts list:
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19687
  • 12-15 V power supply / battery
  • 47 ohm 0,5W resistor
  • 1 kohm 0,5W resistor (2 x)
  • 390 kohm 0,5W resistor
  • 4 kohm 0,5W resistor
  • 450V/1000uF capacitors (6 x. Maximum dimensions are 35 x 65 mm)
  • LED Bargraph display
  • LM3914
  • 7805 Voltage regulator
  • TSAL7200 (or equivalent) IR diode
  • LTR3208E (or equivalent) phototransistor
  • 2N3904 small signal transistor (or equivalent)
  • 50RIA120 SCR (or equivalent). Must be able to survive a current of 7-800 A for the pulse duration (typically 8-10 ms)
  • 47 ohm (5W or higher) current limiting resistor (to be mounted between the boost converter and capacitor bank)
  • 450V capable switch with a 300 ohm/5W minimum current limiting resistor (to be mounted across the capacitors as a safety discharge switch. This is essential in case of a misfire. The capacitors can store a lethal charge for more than a day). The design accommodates a switch with a form factor like an arcade microswitch.
  • carbon fiber tube (5 mm outer diameter). Use a dremel tool to create slots for the infrared light beam.
  • approx 150 grams of 1mm insulated copper wire for the accelleration
    coil. The coil should have a series resistance of approx 0,3-0,4 ohm and an inductance of approx 190 uH (You can counterwind parts of the coil to reduce inductance if you need a higher series resistance). With these parameters the pulse should be critically damped and there will (hopefully) not be a need for additional protection circuitry.
  • plastite screws (12)
    • (The two additional schematics you will need are in the video) PS. varying the length of the projectile can make a really big difference in kinetic energy.

remixed_from.author: jjd64
remixed_from.title: Easily removable prop guard for Moskito 70

description.text:
Primary reason for this is to more easily remove the prop guard. I fly indoors and outdoors... indoors(house), I like the protection, but outdoors, ditching the guard adds a bit of performance (I think ;) ).

This is a remake of jjd64's removable prop guard. Had problems printing his, since the extensions that link the frame to the guard were not strong enough, and the joining was to fragile.

This remake adjusted that. In my opinion it now prints as strong as it can with the size limits.
I also made a little groove in the added pieces to reduce the weight a little without compromising strength.

At best, because of the way this mounts it does have room for movement, so a crash or hard knock will end up with the prop guard hitting the props, but to date I have not damaged props due to the frame.

Also note. If you use this type of prop guard, then you will have to use the extra standoffs you got with the Moskito. You will also need to ensure that all your electronics is tucked away well, since it is now no longer held in by the frame. I might design something that replaces the standoffs and "casing".

EDIT:
Added the inner guard, as mentioned before, just to keep everything tidy... taken from lgb's frame: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2173393

It has 3, standoffs.... this is not a mistake. I preferred it like this, so that I could access the USB port. It's perfectly stable thus far. I have added a four leg version as well

title: OpenLOCK Ruined Columns & Side Locking Walls

description.text:
This is my first dalliance into doing the OpenLOCK side clip standard, and you can really create some cool stuff with this. This ruined set gives you OpenLOCK A walls in all the variations of height, along with all the forms of full height columns and half height columns.

If you want to clip on more then one side of a column at the same height, you'll want to use the stubby clip that's included.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter

title: Mobile Frame Zero: Brunn Schlachtross
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This one doesn't really have a backstory, so I was too lazy to whip up a description "info sheet".

I'll just say that this frame's bulk is comparable to that of the SN-1H, and that it's got a frickin' hyperlaser with a 2m* diameter powered by energy collectors in the chest. When it unleashes hell on enemies, it extends its heel outriggers for stability. Additionally, it's equipped with arm-mounted cluster missile pods and two guided missiles on its "backpack".

TIPS:
-Lateral shoulder rotation is somewhat difficult without breaking the elbow off. To prevent this, grasp the arm by the back of the shoulder and the underside of the forearm for greater leverage.
-Don't attempt to build the Schlachtross in the .lxf file without a palette swap, as 95% (rough estimate) of its pieces don't exist in those colours.

Systems
Defense: Titanium-carbon composite armour
Movement: N/A
Surveillance: N/A
Melee: Fists
Direct Fire: N/A
Artillery: Hyperlaser
x4 Single-Shot Rockets (minifigure legs on backpack)

For more info on Mobile Frame Zero, a Lego-based wargame: http://mobileframezero.com/mfz/

*"m" just so happens to represent metres AND Lego units (modules). Huh. (My frames are in the "human height = 4 plates" scale.)

title: Altimaster II Skydiving Altimeter Night HALO Parts Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an adapter to mate the military style upper lighting assembly and 2xAA battery pack from a fake cosplay Altimaster MA2-30 HALO and night jumper rated altimeter replica to a real unlit civilian Altimaster II civilian skydiving altimeter while retaining the real Altimaster fully intact. I got the inexpensive but very tough fake Altimaster when I realized it was cheaper to buy a whole fake MA2-30 cosplay altimeter just to replace the lost wrist strap and mounting rails than to buy the real Altimaster parts from my rigger or other parachute shops online. As long as I have the lighting parts in my parts bin I though I might as well see if they work together. Without the adapter the fit is not good leaving big gaps and requiring removal of the protective lens from the real Altimaster. If I get brave I might use one of the alternate color and a face decals provided with the cosplay altimeter with 0-12k ft and then 13-24k ft on an inner scale for the second revolution of the needle though the Altimaster II's accuracy is only certified to 18,000 ft.

A MA2-30 is the military version of the Altimaster II, it has an optional different gearing ratio to change the scale from 0-12 to a single sweep of 0-30 thousand feet, several different face markings and colors, and the battery pack and lighting module installed, and a much higher plastic lens to match the built up area containing the red low intensity illumination LEDs.

Economics:
The Altimaster II civilian version sells for about US$180 new with a good pool of used altimeters for sale made over the 30-40 year production of the design; while the MA2-30 (NSN 6685-01-213-9035) is the same thing with the lights and optional different scale for about US$1000, government hammers and all, and if found used sells at a premium as a genuine special operations team collectors item. The cosplay altimeter was US$15 with free shipping, while the best deal for rails and strap was nearly US$30! A better deal if you want genuine jumpworthy Altimaster parts on your civilian Altimaster II is to get the ultra-reliable chemical lightstick lighting adapter, it was US$22.50 when I did my search. This adapter project is a bit of whimsy to play on the ground with otherwise wasted parts, and I wouldn't consider jumping with it though I have coveted a real MA2-30 for many years and would of course jump with that.

Warnings and Use License Conditions:

title: RAMPS Case With Graphic LCD and RJ45 Connectors

description.text:
This is sort of a remix of Dasaki RAMPS case. It was completely re-drawn with added graphical display and RJ-45 connectors for easy stepper connections. The size is increased for extra room for the cabling. It also can accommodate standard and clone MEGA 2560 boards (they differ in USB and power connector placement).

The display piece needs to be rotated in Slicer software and placed flat face down. Two files of display are provided - with and without supports.

The base has two versions - V1 with only one M3 securing sscrew. V2 - with two M3 screws. I did not print V2 myself. Let me know if issues are found.

Hardware required:

M3x10 - 6 pcs (Fan panel and display mount)
M3x12 - 2 ( connector panel mount)
M3x20 - 8 pcs (fans mounts)
M3 nuts ...

RJ45 - Keystone connctors

SKP files are provided for convenience.

author: xyz100

description.text:
For all those who own a Rep and have had a hard time Pulling that x timing Belt into place. For rounder circles and optimum printing!   
To use properly remove the right side panel before fitting the wrench with the handle to your left over the x-motor.
printed with 5 shells and 30 % infill for more stability, layer height is 0.15

I needed some drawers for organizing resistors, capacitors and other small components. I wanted the resistor compartments to have cut-outs on the dividers to make it easier to get the resistors out with fat fingers, and I wanted a lot of customizability in the drawer divider organization. You can also customize the dimensions heavily.

The design is optimized for minimal plastic usage, hence the grid walls for the main chest and the thin dividers in the drawers.

All print with no support at 0.3mm layers. Since all the walls by default are thin, infill percentage makes little difference. I printed in PLA.

The design uses (and bundles) my Bezier library, which is particularly convenient for designing symmetric things (in this case, the cut-outs on long walls).

Update: Outer walls (including floor) can be thicker than inner walls. The defaults in the SCAD file are like that now, which makes it possible to print drawers with even less plastic. Also, by default the handle has no floor now.

description.text:
This tool can be used with tinfoil to create corrugated roof tiles for scale modelling.
The thing contains the tooling for two sizes: one for roughly 1:50 and one for around 1:87-1:100 scale.

Regardless of the size you want you need to print the Pin three times and a single TurningKnob.

Additionally you need to print all the files with the respective size (either Large or Small) to get a complete tool.

You can download the files individually or get the zip-file that contains everything for either size.

Cudos for the idea for making these corrugated by hand goes to Raffaele "Picster" Picca who did the corrugated sheets by hand in his amazing diorama Giu's Robot Repairs. The making of containing the sheets can be found here:
http://massivevoodoo.blogspot.de/2013/11/gius-robot-repairs-part-2.html

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

see below

Notes:

The pins and the turning knob should be printed as solid as possible while the rolls/outside are good with ~30% infill.

The size of the tool can be scaled up by scaling the Roller files asymetrically in only the height axis to enlarge the surface.

Printing the files scaled down for other sizes might result in cracking pins/turning knob depending on material and print quality.

Assembly

Assembly is straight forward but be careful when pressing the pins into the roller. They are quite a snug fit and the best way is to lay the pin on a table, add the size and then press the roller down from the top against the table.

description.text:
This modifications for replacing a original HotEnd Felix for E3D HotEnd. (this mod resolve big problem with filement jam in PEEK on Felix HotEnds). It is also possible to use E3D HotEnd designed for Bowden drive. Benefit:
  • base is reinforced,
  • HotEnd AL heatsink is stay absolutely cold when print on 200°C
    • negative:
    loose some print height ´----------------------------------
    NEW VERSION base and clamp V2. Base reinforced in the point for clamp nut and smaller hole for the filament with conus. Clamp with smaller hole for the filament with conus on both sides.

in file is two files from clamp. Version 2mm is shifted fiber guide about 2mm for precise guidance of the fiber. Tried it yet basic design of the clamp.  
Clamp must print with support  
Assembly:  
Remove the screws that hold the frame stepper motor from the base (no need to remove the motor and the system pressure fibers). Remove the original base.   
Parts that use the original base (screws, belt tensioner).   
Assembly according to the instructions on the original extruder. The fans that cool the HotEnd is required to switch to 12V!

title: Predator Costume Tri-Laser Adapter DIsc
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mount and aim adapter for three laser diode modules removed from cheap laser pointer key chains. This is part of an award winning detailed full body costume of the Predator alien who hunted Arnold Schwarzenegger and his commando team in the 1987 film.
We could have drilled out the holes but stuffing the laser modules in worked, it was a bit tricky to get them aimed into a nice triangle and keep them there with tape. If we had more time I would have potted it all in with epoxy and made a nice housing matching the mask. We had about three hours to find the required parts and make an epic costume for my kid so you will see plenty of tape, hot glue, cardboard, and spray paint used on this costume. Being we had short notice we used mostly junk including irrigation pipe, an Iron Man mask, a sliced up and spray painted old jump rope, spray painted bubble wrap, fishing net, disposable serving platters, and a few 3D printed parts. Despite using very few ideas presented directly we cribbed much inspiration for alternate low budget build paths from this excellent video. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CIqprMxCBV8
Despite the obliquity of cheap lasers this is the first Predator costume I have seen to feature them and we both though it really added a major upgrade to the costume along with green lights to flash the eyes which the Predator did a few times, early in the movie, when stealthed.
We put each laser module in shrink tube and inserted them into the adapter disc. We shorted the old power buttons by soldering a jumper wire across the switch pads and wired the lasers in parallel, shrink tubing all solder joints, to a 4xAA 6v pack from thingiverse(can't find it now) hidden under the shoulder plasma gun and ran a remote trigger wire down the sleeve into a PCB concealed the left glove for surreptitious activation for the eye lights and the laser sights by thumb, there was no time to make pyrotechnical squibs to simulate the firing of the plasma gun but the PCB was wired wired for that too with a safety switch and squib-armed light wired into the mask. The outer edge could have been smaller, and epoxy potting and a printed housing would have made this even better, but we had little time.

title: Ultimate Z Wobble Fix for Duplicator 7
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This Thing is the Best Z Wobble Fix that exist

Description
The function of the conversion and why it works is explained quickly:
No spindle, no Z Wobble.

Z Wobble is a problem caused by spindles and only occurs with spindles

Parts
Motor Mount

  • 6pcs M3x16mm
  • 4pcs M3 Nut

Belt Mount

  • 2pcs M3x25mm
  • 1pc M3x12mm

Bearing Slider

  • 2pcs M5x20mm
  • 2pcs M3x20mm
  • 2pcs M3x30mm
  • 4pcs MF105ZZ

Bearing Top

  • 4pcs M4x16mm
  • 1pc M5x20mm
  • 1pc M3x12mm
  • 1pc M3x16mm
  • 2pcs MF105ZZ

Rest

  • 1pc Pulley GT2 16T
  • 1m GT2 6mm Belt

Software
For this mod, you need to change the steps per mm of the z axis.
This can be done simply by setting the steps per mm to 200 in the Nanodlp terminal with the command M92 Z200. Then you have to save the change with M500 in the EEPROM.
I used the NanoDLP Firmware in my D7

M92 Z200
M500

So have fun with the post-build and if you have any questions, I will gladly answer them.

A storm door had failed due faulty parts that help the hinges to the door frame. The faulty parts were hard to find. Instead of buying a whole new storm door, they were 3D printed. The door is now in working order!

More details on the story and process can be found here:
https://medium.com/@joe_techem/3d-printing-saved-a-storm-doors-life-24e50143ad08

Essentially, the print is a straight cylinder object. A total of three hinges needed two of these prints each, making for six total prints. The build is thick enough so they will not slip out of position. A pair of pliers are needed for installing the door hinge "straight pins".

Updates to the print to come (if the 3D prints fail).

Necessary Modifications to Build

Settings

Layer Height: 0.20mm (instead of 10mm)
Infill: 15% (instead of 10%)
Number of Shells: 3 (instead of 2)

Scaling

x, y = 6.45mm
z = 45mm

The above dimensions will likely vary based on size of door hinge.

The changed settings above reflect a much stronger print. Necessary for holding a heavy door's hinges in place to the door frame. The stock parts were a metal material.

The rest of the settings were left to default.

The summer heat may play a factor to how the 3D printed pins hold up.

Medium Post with Detailed Steps Taken

https://medium.com/@joe_techem/3d-printing-saved-a-storm-doors-life-24e50143ad08

remixed_from.title: Interchangeable Dual Blower/Radial Fan Duct (Tevo Tarantula)

title: The Scorpio: Dual Blower Fanduct + SG90 Servo for Tevo Tarantula

description.text:
UPDATE: Newer, more accurate version here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2744300

This is a remix marrying two beautiful and functional designs into one: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1850163 (Dual Blower fan duct) and this wonderful servo bracket https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:930292.

Printing is difficult, and the design might change in future to try and make it easier to print. Best is to use custom supports, and if you have good adhesion print it upside down. If you don't have custom supports, print it lying on the 'box' and with supports from build plate. You will likely have a lot of cleaning up to do, as there is a lot of bridging.

main body can be printed at 0.2, medium infil. The arm and gear should be printed at around 0.1, no brim, solid.

Whole project was inspired by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1632848 , and the instructions there can be used to setup this project as well.

UPDATE: New design which shifts the arm to the left, allowing better airflow to the hotend. Added arm to use a large Microswitch - my recommendation is to get a Honeywell V7 5F17D8 1796593 , which has an insanely low activation force of just 0.15N. This means minimal pressure on the bed and extremely high accuracy. Bought mine here: http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/351388088028?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Also made the design work off the interchangeable dual blower fanduct here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2346783 which allows greater flexibility on which ducts to use. I am still designing ducts that work well with the wires of the hotend rotated to face the front. Ducts can be found in the link.

Video of design: https://youtu.be/P5GlPdGeo0M

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

comments.text: You mean the mounting to the heatsink fan? Yes, its better, as the arm is now off to the side and does not cover the fan any more. The video should show you what it looks like - if not tell me exactly what part you want to see.
comments.author: hieuktr

comments.text: Thank for reply. I mean the nozzle fan, such the old version with dual blower fan duct because i usually print with PLA.
comments.author: klauscon

comments.text: The mounting for the nozzle fans (blowers) comes directly from the model for the interchangeable fan duct. it is identical. I have found that the fans sit much better than in the old version, but that the ducts themselves can be a pain sometimes as they start sliding out. Nothing a bit of tape wont fix.

title: Fidget spinner small with Stainless Steel Balls
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Part list:

For large bearings:
2x fidget_spinner_small.stl
2x fidget_spinner_cap.stl
6x Steel Bearing Balls (9.525mm/ 3/8")
1x 6201 2RS bearing (12x32x10)

For small bearings (608):
2x fidget_spinner_small.stl
1x fidget_spinner_small_cap_small_bearing.stl
1x screw that has 10 mm long thread
1x fidget_spinner_small_insert_small_bearing.stl
6x Steel Bearing Balls (9.525mm/ 3/8")
1x 608 bearing (8x22x7)

Made a small fidget spinner to my kids with Stainless Steel Bearing Balls (9.525mm/ 3/8")

Bearings was bought from local store "Bilteam"
6201 2RS (12x32x10) and the grease was washed away with some electronic spray but "clean alcohol" or degreasers would do.

The rubber protection was removed to increase the speed even more,

The ball bearings is still a bit slow so i would suggest to substitute them with any ceramic ball bearings in the same size.

Now i bought some small 608 bearings, Inner Diameter: 8 mm, Outer Diameter: 22 mm, Width: 7 mm with ceramic ball bearings.

I created a insert in the old spinner for this "fidget_spinner_small_insert_small_bearing.stl" and some caps that need a screw that has 10 mm long thread, that you need to warm-up and place in the cap with a large hole,

print_settings.Notes:: My first attempt was with the model standing. It looked very good, but the structure proved too weak and I therefore did it lying down the second attempt. leaving me with a little more rough edges because of the support.

description.text: I had heard my Robomow squeeking while it mowed one day and noticed that the right wheel was very wobly. I removed the wheel and found the driveshaft broken inside and therefore searched online to find a supplier. Danish suppliers could only sell it included with the motor and british supplier didn't know if it was in stock. Buying it in the states would mean high cost for shipping, import taxes, local taxes, so I sat down and drew up a simple cad. I had it printed, mounted and running within an afternoon.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2 Extended

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100%

Notes:

My first attempt was with the model standing. It looked very good, but the structure proved too weak and I therefore did it lying down the second attempt. leaving me with a little more rough edges because of the support.

I used an 8mm drill in the big hole and 4mm drill for the small holes, just to get the perfect fit.
With the wheel and motor next to me, I filed and sanded the shaft here and there. Had the mower running again even before the british supplier could reply to my request for purchase.

Removing the drive shaft

description.text: Buckle your safety belts, we're about to get political! On May 22nd, 2012, The God Article, a Christian civil rights organization, posted a status update on Facebook asking its members what they thought was an appropriate response to Pastor Charles L. Worley's comments that the gay and lesbian populations should be "locked inside an electric fence until they die out." Member Michelle McBriarty suggested that members make a donation in Pastor Worley's name to their favorite LBGT charity, and the group immediately jumped on the idea. They created a blog post to organize the response: http://www.thegodarticle.com/15/post/2012/05/a-sinfully-beautiful-response-to-ncs-latest-gay-bashing-minister.html I saw this idea and loved it... it's always best to respond to negativity with positivity, and this response seems like the exact right thing to do here. For my part, I remembered the anti SOPA/PIPA coins from that protest, and thought it would be an awesome idea if folks were able to include a small token representing a couple that they personally know who has been affected by anti-gay bigotry. So... I made these coins. If you will be participating in this protest (and I hope you will) please print out the appropriate coin for the couple(s) that you know, and mail it along with the postcard from that blog page, to remind Pastor Worely that his words have meaning, they hurt real people, and they do not represent the Christian community.

1: Go to http://www.thegodarticle.com/15/post/2012/05/a-sinfully-beautiful-response-to-ncs-latest-gay-bashing-minister.html 2: Make a donation to your favorite LGBT charity. 3: Print out the postcard available on that blog page, or write a letter. 4: Print out one or more coins representing couples that you personally know, to send along with the postcard/letter. 5: Put all of that in an envelope, and mail it off to the address listed in the blog post.

description.text:
I recently got a Prometheus System for dual color printing and after getting it tuned properly, I wanted to try making a dual color model. As I was going to print few of the great Super Roses, I thought that it would make a nice dc print. So I fired up OpenSCAD and started hacking away.

After I was mostly done, I noticed that there's already a version that splits the rose to base and individual petals (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:334788). Well I thought that this model might be a good intermediate step as it divides the rose to 7 different circles, each having a set of petals so I'm publishing this anyways.

Printed without problems and looks quite nice.

Printer:

FrankenCube with Prometheus System

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

Doesn't matter

Notes:

All of the models are positioned relative to each other so there should be no need to move them around.

I used OpenSCAD's import-feature to bring in the original Roses.stl model (download it from the original thing). Then I used intersection() to cut each petal-circle out of the imported model. Took some fine-tuning to get them all fully I tell you.

print_settings.Notes:: If you want to have some more flexibility, just print it with ABS. I first printed in PLA, but removing ends up with a 'broken leg'.

description.text:
This is is a shim spacer, a hight-compensator if you want to use an additional glasplate on your MeCreator 2.
With the leveling screws you are not able to compensate the height of the plate, so the Z-Axis-Endswitch has to be touched earlier. The spacer is made for a plate with 4 mm height.
Just put this shim spacer inside the two holes underneath the Z-endswitch, correct the available Z-workspace in your software from 16 cm to 15,6 cm, fix the glasplate on top of your heatbed, level it again and have fun.

MeCreator 2

author: Olafiolio

description.text: Students use TinkerCad and a Makerbot printer to design and create their own signature stamps for working with clay.

Students usually mark clay and other 3D pieces with their initials as they create them. This is often referred to as a maker's mark. With this project, students will have the opportunity to design and create their own maker's mark or "signature" for their clay pieces. Students have the opportunity to be creative, while working within some pretty specific constraints. There is a lot of opportunity for problem solving, trial and error, and ultimately success. After creating the maker's mark, students will be able to mark each of their pieces in a unique and consistent way, thus identifying themselves as the creator.

Procedure Day 1: Discussion of maker's mark. What is it's purpose? Where are they found? How are they created? Look at some examples from other artists. Day 2: Introduce the activity. Students will be designing for 3D printing their own maker's mark. Demonstrate how to use TinkerCad. Students explore in TinkerCad. Day 3-5: Distribute activity constraints. Students work to design maker's mark. When complete, they download as STL and share with teacher. Teacher prints the objects. Students evaluate their maker's mark, test it out, and redesign if necessary.

• visualization
  • 3d design
  • modeling
  • file type ID

description.text: VESA MOUNT FOR TECKNET HMDI SWITCH

Small cabinet suitable for electronic components. Drawers have dividers to split them into 1/3, 1/2 and 2/3.  
This was printed on a rep 2 with PLA, 1 shell and 5 % infill. No supports are needed.  
Print the case lying on its back ( the stl is oriented that way). The slots in the case are to reduce warpage and to save plastic.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:220720 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=220720

Using the following options: heart_diameter = 20
number_of_steps = 48
line_thickness = 1
line_height = 3

Designed for both standard and larger spools

After starting large prints on my CR-10 i switched to using 2 plus kg of filament. These spools are usually double the size of the standard spools. I therefore designed this to handle the large spools but also allow standard spools to be used

Required

To allow the spool to move without issue the holder is designed to take 608zz bearings (hey have to use the ones left over from fidget spinners somewhere)

Print the item twice and insert the bearings and press together (repeat for both sides) no glue should be needed but feel free to add some if required

Required items:
4 x holder prints
4 x bearing
